title: 113_s2417
content: The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" may impose a lifetime ban on members of Congress from lobbying. The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" proposes a lifetime ban on members of Congress from lobbying. Section 207(e)(1) of title 18, United States Code is amended to restrict former Senators, Members of the House, or elected officers from influencing current members of Congress on behalf of others. Section 207(e)(2) is also amended to clarify the restrictions on staff members. SEC. 3. Congressional staff terms extended to 6 years. SEC. 4. Creation of lobbyists.gov for easy disclosure. SEC. 5. Lifetime ban on Congress members lobbying. Any registered lobbyist or agent of a foreign principal cannot be hired by a Member or committee of Congress within 6 years of leaving their position if they had substantial lobbying contact. A waiver can be granted by the Committee on Ethics or the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct in cases of compelling national need. Substantial lobbying contact includes interactions related to legislative business, solicitation of funding, coordination of meetings, presentations to staff, and fundraising activities beyond personal contributions. Substantial lobbying contacts involve interactions related to legislative business, solicitation of funding, coordination of meetings, presentations to staff, and fundraising activities beyond personal contributions. Simple social contacts with Members or staff do not constitute substantial lobbying contacts. SEC. 6A. REPORTING BY SUBSTANTIAL LOBBYING ENTITIES. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to include reporting requirements for substantial lobbying entities. Substantial lobbying entities must annually file a list of employees or consultants who are former members of Congress or congressional staff meeting specific criteria. The filing should include a brief job description for each individual. The filing required by this section for substantial lobbying entities must include job descriptions and work experience of employees, consultants, or individuals providing paid consulting services. The Joint website lobbyists.gov will have a searchable database for these entities, and filings will be provided to the District of Columbia United States Attorney for oversight of lobbying activities. The District of Columbia United States Attorney will review filings from substantial lobbying entities to determine if they are accurately reporting their federal lobbying activities. A substantial lobbying entity is defined as an incorporated entity with more than 3 federally registered lobbyists. SEC. 7 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to increase penalties from $200,000 to $500,000.
